_joking tone_ Because it affects more than just AD assassins? *badum-tsh*

In seriousness, I think the biggest problem is that Riot is trying so hard to make winrates and pickrates equal by giving champions a chance to be in the spotlight. In my opinion, everyone just needs to relax and look at the design decisions they make.

In order to add something, you are mitigating part of the meta. for example, if you improve tanky items, you reduce the viability of sustain. Thus burst and piercing come into fashion as a compensatory measure. If the game's elements (what Riot has control over), are unbalanced, then the way players play the game effectively compensates for this, creating a balanced meta.

That meta remains stable until another compensatory gameplay style is found, or until the game elements change. From what I've seen in my short time, the game elements are changing very frequently (and sometimes to a large degree) in this game, so the entire meta shifts every other update.

**Rito**: We've noticed Thunderlords is getting picked more than other masteries while only going secondary with  ferocity, so we lowered the number of points you can spend on masteries to one skill trees worth. now if you want a keystone mastery, you have to use all your points in one tree :D

I bet it's just the mains you choose. Fervor is pretty beastly on a lot of attack-speed champions. Deathfire grasp is great for dot/aoe champions, like karthus and teemo (don't let the description fool you. The nerfs to dots are to prevent it from being TOO broken on dot champions). I would just say that, while those two types of champions do make a big splash, League has a lot more burst champions, which is why thunderlord's gets all the action.

I don't get why Deathfire is so hot on DoT/AoE (DoT in particular). Most single-target spell champions can keep DFT up indefinitely without a DoT, as they have a 4-second duration, the same amount as a 3-second DoT. Not many skills get crazy enough durations to obscenely abuse that. I feel Pantheon and Urgot would be best with it, in fact, as they can poke with high power and have basically no lagtime without DFT. The AD focus helps immensely, as well (50% AD is far better than 20% AP).

50% bonus AD isn't better than 20% AP, because AP champions have access to items with higher amounts of AP. As an example, look at Xerath and Zed's most frequent core builds on Champion.gg, Zed at full build has 260 bonus AD from items while Xerath has **648** AP from items.

I think it's more about how long you actually WILL be keeping things up. If you're karthus, you'll be keeping it going for a LOOOOONG time. If you're leblanc though... you basically do you all your damage in a .5 second interval and then walk away for 8 seconds hoping your target is already dead anyway so who cares about dots.

I think to truly identify the advantage of deathfire over thunderlord's, you have to think about how long, during the usual teamfight (which aren't that long usually anyway), you'll be doing damage and to how many champions. Pantheon's in the thick of it for a while, but he only has one short burst aoe (other than his ult), and for the most part focuses a single target, usually a squish that, if he has his way, will be dead in a few seconds anyway. Urgot I can understand more, even though he primarily focuses one or two targets, he spams all day from the beginning to the end of a fight.

Of course there's lane phase to consider also, Panth with deathfire in lane is probably a LOT more effective than thunderlord's. Duel's and trades are a lot more spread out than all-out teamfights.

1. Warlord's Bloodlust is useful to about 3 champions. (Tryn, Yasuo, and maybe Yi.  Maybe.)

2.  Deathfire touch has virtually no base damage and requires a bit of AP or AD to match Thunderlord's damage.  At level 6 you would need 120 bonus AD or 300 AP to match the base damage of Thunderlords alone not counting it's ratios.  Not to mention most of the pokey cast that would thoeratically like Deathfire Touch have AoE poke which gets reduced effectiveness.

3.  Fervor of Battle is decent and pickable on several champions, but since it needs to ramp up in against enemies and doesn't scale it becomes less useful.  It's been nerfed already.   Also if you are doing this you're missing out on a lot of good pen.

4. Stormraider's surge is at odds with Thunderlords.  If I'm playing someone who can burst hard enough to trigger it I'd rather just burst harder and kill them.  Especially since most Assassins already have a slow or evasion ability to stick to their target or get out.  It just doesn't fit into the gameplan of its intended champions.

6. The Penetration offered in Cunning is way better in almost all cases then the percent pen offering in Ferocity.  There is no real cost for going 18 cunning.  It gives you damage, sustain, and an easy to proc nuke.  Either some of that offensive power has to go, or Ferocity needs buffed hard in the damage department.  As it is you get most of the relevant masteries in 12-18-0 already.  So those last 6 points need to be where a tree REALLY differentiates itself, and right now Cunning is far and away the better choice.

Fervor does not give free AD. It gives bonus physical damage to your auto-attacks. It is essentially free AD on autos, but with a key differences: it doesn't boost abilities' scalings, it doesn't crit, and it is treated as an on-hit effect.
